I never had any issues making the biggest mobs of pure ethanol 20 years ago. 10Kg sugar made into a sugar syrup, chuck that into a 40L fermenter, top up with tap water (in my case bore water). Living in the tropics I had to use a temp tollerent yeast and threw that in there as well, gave it a mix with the broom handle and put the lid on.  would start bubbling thru the water trap in a few hours and complete fermentation in less than 6 days 35L at approx 12 - 15%. I made a reflux still from an old 20L tea urn 1m tall 50mm copper pipe for the column with stainless steel scourers and a Nelson head with 2 copper condensors in the vapour trail. This made me 4L of the closest thing you can get to pure ethanol there is in open air. Diluted by 50% transfered to 2.5L juice bottles and added some chipped used bourbon barrels available from the home brew shop (mail order), leave it for a week. Cheapest 8L of Bourbon after 2 weeks from pitching the yeast, very drinkable and got better the longer you let it in contact with the wood chips.
Use copper coil to remove sulphates, this will make it smell and taste much better.

The optimum temperature for growth of yeasts is in the mesophilic range of 25–30 °C. Yeasts in general can grow over a range of temperatures from 0 °C to 47 °C. Yeasts grow well under acid conditions, at pH 4.0–4.5. They can grow at lower pH than most bacteria, but do not grow well under alkaline conditions.




A mesophile is an organism that grows best in moderate temperature, neither too hot nor too cold, with an optimum growth range from 20 to 45 °C. The term is mainly applied to microorganisms. Organisms that prefer extreme environments are known as extremophiles.

NEVER use distilled water if you don't plan to add minerals back later.
Here is a cheap sugar wash recipe (for 5L)
- 500g of sugar
- water to 5L (without chlorine!)
- boil the mix for few minutes to kill any microbes in it.
- Add 1/2 packet of baker's yeast to the boiling water. This will be your nutrients
- Add the juice of 1/2 lemon (lowering the pH keeps at bay many spoilage organisms)
- 1/4th of a packet of EC - 1118. Add it in your fermenter when it has cooled down to 15-25C.
Clean the fermenters and all brewing equipment with starsan (diluted solution can be reused many times).
When it clears up, put it in the fridge for few days and syphon the supernatent in clean and sanitized bottles. You shoud get a 5% ABV drink. It tastes OK if you cut it with juices.
If you want a buzz and distillation is not allowed where you live, look into cryo-fractionation / freeze-jacking. It does wonders but the yield is bad and the hangover terrible.

I know that this is a chemistry class and all but why are you making it so god damn complicated. Its simple pick your favourite flavour, for example apples, grapes, even flowers work! If the flavour of your choosing doesn't contain sugar or yeast you just add it( while figuring out the ratios) put it in a large tank. Wait until all the sugar has been eaten by the yeast, you measure that with sugar meter. When there isn't much sugar you distil it. When boiling it remember to take out some of the starting fluid because its methanol and its poisonous. Distil it until the alcohol meter shows 40 degrees then save the rest for redestination. Leave the distilled alcohol to rest several months with good flow of air in order to clean it as much as possible from methanol and bam you got yourself your own rakia. You should be so clean and all of that. I've made tons of this thing and its amazing. Have done it with roses, grapes, apples, pears, acacia, blue plum, figs, and i really want to do one from watermelon. Aways drink a little bit while testing it in order to see if there isn't something wrong, and never drink it fresh leave it for couple of months!! Brew at your own risk!

If you gotta use copper stills make sure it's silver Sautter. I would strongly recommend stainless steel. And you do not need to use distilled water if you have a well. Go  Purchase rubber made garbage cans to make your mash in. You need  Brewer  Yeast. You can use corn or use  Sugar. Run the still at about 170 Or run at bare minimum alcohol blows at a 168.6ﾟF. Pay attention to your heat exchanger. If you condense too quick it'll come out with a mean bite that Burns when you drink it. If it's cloudy don't drink. Should be clear as water. Go ahead and invest in a hydrometer so you can see what your proof is. Also try to brew in the least amount of humidity. Less humidity more alcohol. You can use a counter top 1500 W still or you can make One that runs on propane or natural gas. If you're gonna do it the old fashioned way on an open fire go ahead and put a thump keg between  The heat exchanger barrel. That helps keep water vapor out of the alcohol during the open fire distill. What ingredients you make mash with will depend on your batch turn out

Why wouldn't it taste good if aged? Rum is made from cane sugar. The distillation process leaves the ethanol very pure 90%+ and then water is added to dilute it to cask strength (~70% - for whiskey at least but still same point) and then diluted again after aging - Bacardi ages 1 year - and then usually diluted to ~40%. Rum is a low end liquor to me, it is in fact, but it's not bad. Needs heavy sugar and dilution usually. Age it in some oak barrels for at least 4 years and I bet it'd be just fine.

This video shows how to do a simple thing the hardest way.

You can just dump sugar in hot tap water, dissolve it, add cold/warm water to get the temp down baby bottle temp and dump in the yeast packet. 2 minutes. There are ways to speed up the ferment such as adding diammonium phosphate which is basically yeast fertilizer. You really don't need an airlock. Just loosen the jar lid. You can taste when its done. If you don't taste sugar, it's done. And the resulting 15% alcohol doesn't taste bad at all. Tastes like cheap wine because that's what cheap wine is. Matter of fact, you could skip the whole process by simply running a gallon of box wine through a still.

Also, it's kind of pointless to use distilled water since it's getting DISTILLED. If I were to go out and buy water, I'd get the spring water, as the yeast will like its mineral content a lot better.

Also too, if you use a pot still as opposed to a reflux still, you'll need to re-run the alcohol through the still a few times to get it up close to pure ethanol. Alcohol attracts water so it tends to bring a lot of water molecules with it when it is distilled using a pot still.

It's probably cheaper, now, and hugely faster, to buy hand sanitizer by the gallon and distill that (80% -> azeotrope). The stuff is now about $13/gallon in home improvement stores. Some has a small amount of isopropanol; some doesn't. You probably but not necessarily want the type that doesn't contain isopropanol, depending what you're doing with the result. Hydrogen peroxide and glycerol aren't issues in distillation nor are small amounts of other gunk.

I use it to make anhydrous alcohol. I run it through a fractional column fast (many drops/sec) using temps below, dry it over 3A sieves down to density ~ 0.79, then distill that again to get rid of sieve dust.

Note: Ethylene glycol is not an allowed ingredient in hand sanitizer in the US. (!) Propylene gylcol and/or glycerol are common and safe even in food. "Glycol alcohol" is a synonym for glycerol. Again, ethylene glycol is not allowed in US hand sanitizer. It wouldn't distill over anyway, nor will glycerin or propylene glycol.

Isopropanol on the other hand is impossible to eliminate at atmospheric pressure due to a boiling point almost identical to ethanol. Vacuum distilling at low temperature (working up from freezer temp) might work as the boiling points are farther apart under decent vacuum (0.05 bar or lower). I should try that.

Collect till about 175F (80C). Save that (then dry it). A fair bit will be left in the boiling flask. Collect while distilling to something higher. 195F is good (90.5C). Save that and redistill it later by adding to a later run. You can also save the leftover stuff and redistill that too to around 208F (97.5C), then redistill that etc.

For the density measurement I'm using a 100ml class A volumetric flask and an analytical balance, but you can actually get a very accurate feel for near 100% by letting a small amount evaporate from your fingers. The feel with even small amounts of residual water is much different than the feel with no residual water -- there is no briefly lingering "wetness" - it evaporates cleanly like acetone, just slower.

Yield is around 60% (20% H2O + losses getting the sieves wet etc) or a little higher depending how much you redistill the "tails."

This also gives you flavorless ethanol, should that be of importance.

As far as the flavor of the stuff from fermentation goes, fractional distillation (perhaps multiple times) along with activated charcoal would help, but I'm sure there are congener azeotropes that can't be dealt with. The congeners are important in the flavor of distilled beverage alcohol. Vodka involves multiple distillations and probably charcoal to get rid of them. Adding a pass through vacuum distillation would help.

You might think of distilling E85 but I wouldn't bet on being able to get rid of the hydrocarbon azeotropes.

You brew like a chemist lol there are so many things you could have done to help this ferment clean. You absolutely do need nutrient, ESPECIALLY when you’re only fermenting simple sugar. It also looks like you let you yeast hydrate too long before pitching, you shouldn’t go past 25 minutes. Aging is also important because yeast can process and reabsorb toxins and off flavors produced during stressed fermentation, and other co2 and other gases produced during ferm will continue to come out of solitution.

No need for distilled water. Unless..your tap water is chlorinated. I use plain tap water, pour sugar in, add a teaspoon of tomato paste for each 10 l and throw the yeast in (normal bakers yeast will do). The tomato paste's sole purpose is to add some nutrients for the yeast in order to prevent the yeast from producing too many unwanted byproducts (stressed yeast).
It ferments dry within a week depending on the temperature.
It CAN be distilled in a simple pot still, I'd prefer a reflux still, though.
Tip: distill it twice or even triple and you'll get excellent neutral alcohol. Remember to take the foreshots and do good cuts. Foreshots are to be tossed, heads and early tails can be added to the next stripping run (the first distillation).
Happy stilling. :)

I just buy a $1 gallon of Great Value distilled water from Walmart. Pour a quarter of it out, add sugar in a funnel until it's almost full, top off with a packet of yeast, then slightly twist the cap until the CO2 can escape, but air can't get on. This costs about $2. No need for equipment or sanitization. For distillation, it'll get a little more complicated, but I usually just rubberband a couple coffee filters over the jug once complete and empty it into another gallon jug. This removes most of the yeast. Now you have a 15% or so product you can add to mix drinks. You have to use a little more than twice as much compared to store bought, but remember it was $2 for a gallon lol

This video contains false information. You are more likely to get stuck when you are fermenting just single or two chained sugars in water... This is probably why you are using a insane innoculation ratio of yeast. Wort, for example, are less likely to stall as it contains just what the yeast needs in trace minerals, amino acids etc, to reproduce. Think about it NileRed, how long would you last eating bread and water compared to sugar and water?

Also its bullshit that the environment for yeast to produce alcohol has to be oxygen-free. Read up about the Crabtree effect. Yeast will very very seldom do aerobic fermentation even in the presence of oxygen at the sugar concentrations that we use in fermentation.

comment_text: I've been experimenting with my own home brewing with sugar, apples, and active dry bread yeast. I don't think you need to use as much yeast as you did in this video - it's a biological organism that will multiply exponentially, after all. If you have some kind of food (like apples), you can even use some material from your last batch as starter for your next, and not have to keep using packets. Also, in my experiments, the yeast will produce alcohol even if you leave the top of the bottle open. The airlock is more to keep unwanted organisms out, and to suppress the activity of any aerobic microbes that made it in before the seal was in place. By contrast, if you ever try to make kombucha, you are using an anaerobic alcohol yeast and an aerobic acetic bacteria that work together at the same time, and you need to give the brew some air.

I recommend using corn sugar (dextrose) as yeast can't "digest' disaccharides.  Dextrose will result if fewer of the 'exotic' alcohols being formed.  The same is true for adding yeast nutrients.  Also, making a cooling coil (coiled up copper tubing through which you run cool water) will not only let you cool that syrup faster but will also provide some pasteurization.  I also recommend starting the fermentation in a bucket to allow more head space for the foam of early fermentation.  Use a tight fitting lid with a hole plugged by an airlock.  When the foam subsides, transfer to a bottle style carboy like in the video.

Here's a few tips:
you use far more yeast than necessary. This won't give a bad result but just end up being a waste of resources. I've introduced a single pack to a 5gallon batch in an even more stark environment for the yeast and felt no repercussions.

It's helpful to aerate the mixture some, either by sloshing, whisking, or stirring. This gets oxygen dissolved in the water which is needed by the yeast in small quantities to reproduce. Only do this in the initial couple days as beyond that there's already enough oxygen in circulation for an anaerobic fungus like yeast.

siphoning off the fermented liquid after the yeast settles to the bottom is an effective and easy way to clean the mixture without need for activated charcoal or forced filtration methods. I find no more than 3 repetitions necessary most of the time


If you really want to clear it up simple bentonite clay and siphoning will have it looking crystal clear

There is also another reason to use yeast nutrients than prevent stuck fermentations. It is to prevent stressed out yeast that creates off flavors in a wort that lacks nutrients. Sugar is completely devoid of nutrients so while yeast happily consumes it they are still starving and create a lot of bad tasting off flavors. This is why it is recommended to use yeast nutrients when making mead for example because honey is also very nutrient poor, being mostly sugar. It reduces the amount of time you need to age it before it tastes good. I believe this would be the same for sugar wash if you plan to drink it. It will probably taste less bad if you use nutrients.

Cheap, easy home-made turbo-yeast alternative.
Boil 4 oz. wheat-germ in 1 qt. clean water for 3-4 hours.
When the oils on the surface clarify, it is ready.
Cool the liquid, do not strain!
This is the starter nutrient solution.
Aerate the solution for a day or so; yeast needs O2 to reproduce.
Two cups soln. to one yeast packet; sprinkle the yeast on the surface, stir a little.
There is not a lot of sugar in this stuff, the yeast will reproduce then settle down...but they will be hungry!
After about a day, add this starter mix to your wash. Make sure the wash and starter are close to the same temperature; yeast hates thermal shock!
Wheat germ has all the vitamins, lipids, complex carbs, minerals and phyto-nutrients yeast could ever want.
Yeast needs lipids; if it has nothing but sugar to eat, it has to work hard to make fats. Fats on hand, yeast is on easy street. Yeast cell-wall is a lipid bi-layer, they are made of fat!

I make beer regularly and I never sterilize the pot I'm brewing in. You just have to clean it to remove solid particles, but since you are boiling the water in it and the sterilizing is to kill other bacteria that could harm the yeast or effect the end result it needs no extra chemical sterilization. Everything post-boil needs to be sterilized since it is not sterilized by the boil. You also could avoid the extra possible contamination when stirring in the yeast by rocking and shacking the fermenter (assuming it's the same kind you are using) to mix in the yeast. It will mix in anyways since the yeast will grow and move around when the fermentation is occurring, bad mixes just make the startup take longer

I'm not sure if someone already said this, but you want to make the wash oxygen rich when you pitch the yeast.  While in the aerobic state, yeast reproduces and stores  adenosine triphosphate.  You also have to pitch less yeast.  When the yeast goes into the anaerobic state (all of the oxygen used up), that's when you get your alcohol.  Starting the yeast in an anaerobic state stresses the yeast, and will cause genetic drift in less generations; making re-pitching not advisable.  You also do not have to be very sterile with the wash, as the high alcohol will kill almost anything.  You probably have a lot of non-fermented sugars with not letting the yeast run its full cycle of aerobic to anaerobic; and you may have diacetyl if you don't let the yeast run its full course (you'll end up with a disproportionate amount of tails in your distillation).

As others have mentioned, there is a bit of misinformation and unnecessary steps. You really don’t need to sterilize things, though it should be obvious that boiling your water/sugar gets you a sterile solution. I figure that your yeast will outcompete and poison any other microorganisms, and since you’re not drinking the result means you’re not going to poison yourself.
It’s a myth that you must maintain an anaerobic environment; as long as there is still sugar present to feed your yeast you won’t have your ethanol being digesting into acetic acid/vinegar.
It’s pretty important to get an optical refractometer or specific gravity tester and to test your yeast/sugar solution before it starts fermenting! Either device is extremely cheap, ranging from $5-$15, with the refractometer being a bit more expensive, though definitely easier to test with since you can just add a few drops of your solution to test. Either way be sure to test the solution since virtually all the online calculators require a starting reading to get something approximating an accurate result. You may not want to calculate anything, but it’s far worse if you do end up needing to and you don’t have that critical first reading.

You really don't need to sterilise the vessel you are going to boil the water in. It will be sterilised by heating up to 100°C. Similarly, you don't need distilled water as you will kill any nasties in it by boiling. However, avoiding chlorinated water might well help the yeast. One easy way to get rid of chlorine is to boil the water, though if your tap water contains chloramine you might need to get rid of it another way. Or use water straight from a mountain stream. Why not? You're boiling it after all. My house is fed directly from a mountain spring, and I have fermented many a wine using it.
You do however need to sterilise the fermentation vessel, the funnel, the bung and airlock. i.e. the parts that could or will come into contact with the cooled sugar+yeast solution.

The problem with your method is that you have NO nutrients at all. I have never had good yields fermenting just pure sugar and water (I have tried). The fermentation also takes a lot longer with lower yield and it tastes terrible. The yeasts need some nutrients. You can't feed your kids nothing but candy bars for breakfast, lunch, and dinner and expect them to get into a good college. Yeast may be a bit simpler than children, but you can't feed them pure sugar and water and expect them to thrive. You don't have to get very fancy to introduce some vital nutrients into the solution. Some people swear by adding a can of tomato paste, but I think those people are idiots. It does improve fermentation, but the distilled results tastes like ketchup. Using tomato paste makes no sense to me. My favorite technique is to fortify the yeast with one slice of whole wheat bread for every 5 gallons of solution. I use a blender to make breadcrumbs, but it doesn't need to be ground that small. You can just tear the bread into small pieces. The yeast will grow faster and ferment for vigorously than with pure sugar and water.

Sterilization is unnecessary. Don't get me wrong, a fermentation vessel should be clean. I wash mine with hot water, but I don't get more complicated than that. You are going to be inoculating the solution with about 140 billion cultivated yeast cells. Within a hour the population of your solution is going to be populated by 99.9999% yeast, all healthy and multiplying fast. Any wild microbes will be overwhelmed. If you were making beer or wine then, yes, wild yeasts and bacteria will have enough time to grow and perhaps alter the flavor. So in the case of beer and wine you do need to be more sterile (does Lambic beer count?) But for neutral alcohol distillation wild microbes will not have enough time to develop a competing population that could have any effect on the distilled alcohol flavor or yield. I let my solutions ferment for 5 to 7 days. Once the fermentation slows down everything is immediately put into a boiler and distilled. I taste little difference between one run and another. I've never had a batch go off and taste spoiled. There just isn't time for that to happen.

Another thing you can dispense with is the fiddly airlock. It's true that oxygen is bad, but you can simply wrap aluminum foil loosely over the bottle opening (if you are using small fermentation bottles ~ 5 gallon bottles). The foil keeps out air and dust. The airspace in the bottle is quickly filled with nothing but CO2 and water vapor generated by fermentation. There will be positive pressure in the bottle. Air can't get back in. It would probably be fine even without the foil cover. If you have larger fermentation tanks (starting around 20 gallons) then just try to keep the openings small and minimize the headspace above the solution (run the fermenter full). I use a giant stock pot (25 gallons, 100 quarts, ~95 Liters) with a lid. I keep the lid on snug with spring clips, but it's certainly not airtight. You don't want airtight! Once the solution starts to ferment it is going to generate positive pressure in the fermenter. This CO2 will push out any air and oxygen. It will keep doing this during the entire fermentation process and it will keep doing it even a little after since I normally start to distill the solution before yeast activity has completely stopped. Tested with a refractometer I get between 10% to 14% alcohol. I think the majority of the alcohol seems to be formed by day 4. I usually stop the fermentation early, around 10% on day 5. If I wait another 5 days then I might get up to 14%, but it seems like it's not worth the wait just for an extra 4%. I've been meaning to study this to figure out when to best stop the fermentation and move to distillation. There must be a best strategy based on the cost of mixing up a new solution to ferment, the cost of time to wait for each 1% of alcohol, and cost to distill a batch to 70% alcohol.

Finally, I use ordinary bread yeast. Activated dry yeast works great. I have tested high-yield yeasts and champagne yeasts, but the difference is not significant enough to warrant the expense and trouble. I am suspicious that these specialty breeds of yeast actually yield that much more alcohol than bread yeast. I think the highest I got was 16%, but someone threw out my notes. Can any yeast get much higher? I suspect most of the difference in these specialty yeasts is due to the fact that they always include yeast nutrients mixed with the yeasts. You can buy the yeast nutrients separately and they do help boost yield and speed fermentation time. There is also a difference in flavor. I think the high yield yeasts yield a distilled product that tastes weird. The results taste like ground up multi-vitamin pills (try chewing a multi-vitamin sometime). Open a pack of the fancy high-yield yeast and smell. It does not smell nice. I'm pretty sure it's because of the nutrients added. Whereas yeast for baking bread smells nice. Well, at least, it doesn't smell bad. You kind of have to adjust your notion of what smells nice when you are running a fermentation tank.

I did this. Before distillation I added a couple of grams of potassium permanganate to the wash. According to some sources, this oxidizes a lot of the badly tasting impurities that you get in the distillate (I think the english term is "heads". It's other alcohols, esters and oils with similar boiling point as the ethanol) and gives them a higher boiling point, making them easier to separate through distillation.
I think it also oxidizes some of the ethanol, so you'll lose some in the process. But that's ok for me.

There's some misleading information in here. You need yeast nutrient precisely because you're just fermenting sugar.

Yeast, like people, find it difficult to survive on energy alone. They also need nutrients for their metabolic pathways to function correctly. In the case of yeast it's mainly calcium, zinc, oxygen and free amino nitrogen that's needed.

The only reason why you're getting it to work is because your dry yeast is packed full of various nutrients during manufacture. But as soon as it starts multiplying, that source begins to run out. If you added yeast nutrient for successive generations to utilise you'd get a quicker, more efficient and more complete fermentation with (probably more importantly for you), far fewer cogeners such as higher alcohols, aldehydes, esters, etc which can distil over.

Also you don't need distilled water. You're heating it anyway so there's no need to worry about microbial contamination from it and you're just further reducing the amount of nutrients available for the yeast.

Finally you're using enough yeast for 100 litres

+NileRed, FYI, it should be called either 'must' or 'wort' before fermentation, 'wash' when it is destined for the still (probably 'must' since you are not doing a 'mash'.

Your fermentation was very (very) slow. The primary fermentation should be so vigorous that the airlock you are using would be insufficient (I typically use a tube in a bucket at first, and switch to an air lock when it slows down). You might also need more headroom if you get the fermentation going like it should go, so you don't blow off valuable wort/must. You may want to consider adding yeast nutrients when you are using purified sugar. Nutrients should provide not only a quicker, but a more complete fermentation.

Pure powdered glucose is a bit more expensive than table sugar, but it definitely works better; it dissolves instantly, produces less CO2 and odors, and has better yield. It also tastes a lot better if that's the planned use.

Well, yah, the wash is going to taste terrible. You are missing a vital point in the processes of making drinking spirits.
Spirit makers distill ALL their mashes for a reason. First for getting the alcohol out of the original mash. Second for concentrating the alcohol content even further. And third to get rid of the (more) poisonous by products of the fermentation.
Distillers call it cutting the (Devil's) Head, Heart, and Tail. The heart is only 1/2 to 3/4 of the fermented product.
Point of fact you can still use the Head and Tail for your cleaning solution while making a drinkable product from the Heart.
After recovering the drinkable portion of the fermentation process there are various other things that can be done to mellow and flavor the alcohol. Filtering it through charcoal mellows the alcohol and can benefit all alcohol intended for drinking. Then ageing after that you can drink it after, or you can age it in various ways to impart flavors. Whether that is ageing it in wood barrels for years to make a whiskey or rum, just steeping various things in it to produce a gin, or even doing nothing and getting a vodka like drink is all up to you.

I've been brewing for many years. A lot of the steps shown here aren't as important as implied. Local tap water is fine as long as it's not overly chlorinated. When using a turbo yeast use about 2 1/2 lbs of sugar per gallon. Dissolve the sugar into hot water, it doesn't need to be close to boiling. Cool down to less than 100 degrees and pitch your yeast. You can stretch turbo yeasts out further than they suggest, I can get (2) 5 gallon batches out of one packet. Closely monitor your wash for the first couple hours as turbo yeasts are explosive and will foam up heavily. After that seal up and add the airlock. He also doesn't mention that you need to aerate the wash as the yeast need that oxygen in the wash especially during the first 24 hrs. Some use aquarium pumps, I simply use my faucet's spray nozzle to fill my bucket. After 5-7 days you have up to a 20% wash. For making pure ethanol turbos are ideal but not recommended for grains or fruit. After distilling I add extracts and sugar to make my cordials and have had great success. Been offered $50 for a 750ml bottle but I don't make to sell, I simply give bottles away to family/friends. Homemade stills work but I've discovered the 6 gallon stainless steel rigs you can buy online are perfect and work beautifully. I got mine for about $350 shipped. It is a wonderful hobby.

Yeast nutrients (also availible at brew store and very cheap) can prevent stuck fermentation, reduce the amount of starter yeast needed, and speed the fermentation. These commonly are various mixes of ascorbic acid, urea, and clean yeast hulls(absorbs byproducts that harm the live yeast) a few may contain a trace of minerals.

generally speaking, to obtain the least impurities, dextrose should be used instead of sucrose. while sucrose will produce alot of ethanol, the chemical breakdown performed by the yeast will always produce more impurities such as methanol, acetone and esters. while this can be minimized by using a distillers yeast such as the many turbo brands available, (my preference is still spirits brand, as they are one of the only companies that put in serious r&d into their yeast, while most others just copy them) it will always produce more impurities with sucrose then dextrose, it's just how the math works.

temperature can also play a large part in this, especially in terms of ester production at higher temperatures. (above 35°c) ideally, your wash will be maintained between 20-30°c.

the clarity of your wash before it goes into the still can make an enormous difference at the quality of the final product. at the high temperature the boiler of the still gets to (relative to the volatiles the yeast cells produce) it can cause the yeast cells to rupture, causing various volatiles (essentially precursors to the various alcohols produced) to be released into the wash, which will be distilled through to the final product which will result in lower purity and quality.

activated carbon becomes steeply ineffective at alcohol concentrations above 40%. the best way to produce a high purity product using activated carbon is, after distillation with a refluxing still, dilute with distilled water to around 30-40% ethanol, add the carbon and agitated for 10 minutes or so (this is definitely overkill) filter, (a cotton plug is ideal as filter paper may not remove the fine carbon dust) and redistill using a reflux still.

adding carbon to the wash is not really recommended and is far less effective and a less efficient use of the carbon, as the combination of the distillation process, and the reflux rejection of many impurities, will leave less work for your carbon to do, requiring less carbon, as well as there being less chance of the carbon being gunked up be yeast cells, proteins etc which would reduce efficiency.

Sterilization is wholly unnecessary and excessive. Sanitization is plenty sufficient as anything undesirable will be killed in the remaining processes. Not to mention that their numbers would be so low after sanitization that even (somehow and surprisingly) if one or two cells managed to somehow survive the processing up through the fermentation initiation, the "largest numbers win" factor comes into play too Star-san (phosphoric acid and deodecylbenzenesulfonic acid [mainly as a foaming agent]), a 2% iodophor solution, a weak bleach solution or a sodium percarbonate solution is plenty sufficient. Make sure that you have a 2 minute contact time with anything that will touch the liquids and you will be set.

**A note if you do use star-san, don't fear the foam. You don'thave to get every bit of foam out. In fact, a small to medium amount of foam is actually beneficial to the yeast.

Also, you should probably make a starter for your yeast, especially since you are using dry yeast which tends to have a much lower active cell count than liquid yeasts do. For that, just make a smaller sugar wash and aerate it well, then place on a stir plate for a few hours to a day with the re-hydrated yeast added. This will build up your supply of viable yeast and ensure that you are adding healthy yeast as well which can improve your yield. I find that a 1L erlenmeyer flask is perfect for this. For the purposes of a starter, the aeration can just be shaking the heck out of the flask prior to the yeast addition.

Another thing to mention, is that sucrose alone isn't really the best yeast food. It is lacking in micronutrients that will help them do their best possible job and to give you the highest possible yield. Therefore, I cannot abide by the recommendation to skip the yeast nutrient. In addition to the nutrient, it is advisable to aerate the full wash as well so as to introduce more oxygen into the wash for the yeast to use during its initial growth and reproduction phase. The best method seems to be to bubble just plain air (filtered of course) through the wash from a fine aeration stone (preferably a stainless steel one that is 1 or 2 micron) for anywhere from a few minutes to an hour or so. One nice thing about using plain filtered air is that you cannot over-saturate the wash with oxygen this way. There are people who use oxygen gas through an aeration stone for a few seconds and as long as you are careful and don't over-oxygenate the wash it is fine to do that as well. However, if you over-oxygenate the water the yeast can start to behave in a non-desirable way (for more details on this behavior, look into the "crabtree effect" on yeast.) So, personally, I recommend sticking with just air.

These few things will ensure that your yeast is healthy and happy for the longest period possible during the fermentation process and will increase your yields as healthy yeast will generally tolerate higher ethanol levels in the ferment.

Really .... You should go watch the pros. You can only get about 85% of the 128oz of a 20% mash or wash without a lot of work. If you pull your 4 cuts right ( 5% four shots 1st cut, 30%-40% heads 2nd cut, 30%-40% hearts 3rd cut and 20% tails 4th cut) all four distille at different temps (140 F - 190 F) all them are way before water @ 210 F. Out of all four cuts you only safely keep the HEARTS. You throw the other three cuts out. The first two cuts are very toxic and the tails you keep for your next batch. If you do the math it's about 6.5 oz of hearts per each 1 gallon of 20% ABV mash distilled. You wil pison yourself if you try and filter and drink anything other then the hearts

What I dont understand is why you would build a pot still if you want experiment grade ethanol ??
You want high purity clean stuff for reagent so you would use fractionating methods.   for small amounts like this you would be better off using lab glass.

A good reflux set up should get you to 98% purity.  But a pot still wont come close to that

Also you do no really have to rehydrate the yeast.  just dump it in and it will be fine.  you can bubble in  air for a few hours if you want a lot of yeast to grow.

Also for a little jug like that  you can simply put a piece of plastic wrap over the top with a rubber band. the co2 will get out.  I have never ever in my life seen a wash done this way get infected.

Just a few tips:
High alcohol yeast should be able to reach about 21%.  Not sure how long it would take, probably a month.  I usually make wine with an ABV of 13-16%.
Adding some citric acid and yeast nutrient helps speed up the process.
Potassium metabisulfite is a good sterilizer, but expensive.  Regular bleach works just as well for sterilizing equipment, as long as it's well rinsed.  Still need the metabisulfite if you're working with fruit and you want to kill the wild yeasts in the "must".
